Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Yakov Shlapentokh-Rothman is "The black hole stability problem." The host institution for the fellowship is Princeton University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Mihalis Dafermos.

POR.DRECONTENT:
One of the most central objects of general relativity are black holes and the singularities that they may encircle. My rearch during this fellowship explored various aspects of both the exterior and interior of black holes, as well as provided insight into the nature of singularities in general relativity.

 

I started by carrying out a sequence of projects with Otis Chodosh which concerned the "uniqueness" of black holes. We showed that, depsire standard beliefs to the contrary, in some natural situations it is possible to have exotic periodically oscillating black holes.

 

In another sequence of works, joint with Mihalis Dafermos, we studied the nature of singularities inside black holes. Working in the context of a suitable model problem we established results which indicate the expected "strength" of the singularity and which concern how "generic" the singular behavior in the black hole is. In a related work, joint with Christoph Kehle, we studied the scattering of waves inside a black hole; in particular, we directly relate the behavior of incoming waves into the black hole with the behavior of waves along the cauchy horizons. This analysis is then useful in studying the singular behavior of waves in the black hole interiors.

 

Finally, in a joint work with Igor Rodnianski, we studied "self-similar" singular solutions to the Einstein equations. These are singular solutions which have the same structure when you zoom in or zoom out. Such self-similar solutions arise in many interesting dynamical situations in general relativity.
